prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: COSMOS 13985 CO(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal targets the CO(3-2) line in band 3 for COSMOS 13985 at z=2.1659.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have selected a correlator setup with bandwidth of 1875 MHz and resolution of 31.25 MHz, corresponding to a resolution of 85 km/s. Given that we will integrate the CO(3-2) line flux over a 162 km/s interval, without concern for the detailed line profile, this resolution is sufficient.
Based on the predicted continuum flux density level, we do not expect any detections in the three other basebands. However, we can stack the data for our targets to measure the average continuum level.

As our goal is to obtain a single significant detection of the CO(3-2) line flux for the target galaxy, we are not concerned about mapping the emission. At an angular resolution of 1", our target will be unresolved, but will be sufficient to avoid confusion from neighboring galaxies. The spatial extent of the target should not exceed 2", based on HST rest-frame UV and optical imaging. Accordingly we have chosen the C36-3 configuration with a resolution of 1.2" and MRS of 25.2".

Our goal is to obtain a 5-sigma detection of CO(3-2) emission for COSMOS-13985, integrated over the velocity FWHM of the feature. Here we assume that the velocity FWHM of H-alpha emission, which we have measured from the MOSDEF K-band spectrum of COSMOS-13985, serves as a good proxy for the CO linewidth, and adopt this value of 162 km/s as our bandwidth.
We calculated the peak flux density as follows: First, we use the dust-corrected H-alpha luminosity to estimate a dust-corrected SFR. We combine this SFR with the rest-frame UV size of the galaxy estimated from HST imaging to obtain the SFR surface density. We then use the Kennicutt-Schmidt relation from Genzel et al. (2010) to estimate the molecular gas surface density, and the HST size to obtain the molecular gas mass. We use a Milky Way value of alpha_CO = 4.36 to obtain the CO(1-0) luminosity, and a ratio of CO(3-2)/CO(1-0) line luminosities of 0.75 (Riechers et al. 2010) to estimate the CO(3-2) line luminosity. The measured MOSFIRE redshift is used to calculate the observed CO(3-2) line flux in Jy km/s. Finally, we divide by the observed MOSFIRE H-alpha FWHM (and multiply by 1000) to obtain the peak flux density in mJy. For COSMOS-13985, the peak flux density is 2.29 mJy. Requiring that this flux density is detected at 5-sigma leads to our request of 458 microJy RMS over the specified bandwidth. Deviations in the measured and predicted CO(3-2) line fluxes will indicate possible variations in alpha_CO.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: As the fuel for star formation, molecular gas (H2) is an important component of understanding galaxy evolution. However, the use of CO lines to infer H2 at high redshift suffers from uncertainties related to the conversion between CO luminosity and H2, i.e., alpha_CO, which may depend on metallicity. Here, we aim to use measurements of CO(3-2) to robustly calibrate alpha_CO for a sample of 9 star-forming galaxies at z=2.0-2.6 in the COSMOS field, drawn from the MOSFIRE Deep Evolution Field (MOSDEF) survey. MOSDEF galaxies are characterized by several key measurements enabling this calibration. These include precise spectroscopic redshifts, HST imaging to measure galaxy sizes, and rest-optical spectra that enable the measurement of dust-corrected star-formation rates (SFRs) and oxygen abundances. Dust-corrected SFRs and sizes imply H2 masses through the Kennicutt-Schmidt Law. The comparison of H2 gas mass and measured CO(3-2) luminosities as a function of metallicity for the well-characterized MOSDEF sample will provide important constraints on the variation of alpha_CO with metallicity.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
